awd_titl_txt: Holey Graphene-Supported Single Metal Atoms as Highly Efficient Electrocatalysts
awd_abstract_narration:
Electricity can provide the needed energy for chemical reactions such as the splitting of water into hydrogen and oxygen. Electrocatalysts are materials that are often needed for efficient and cost-effective electricity-driven, chemical reactions. Single atom catalysts (SACs) are composed of single, isolated metal atoms held on solid base (support).  Supported electrocatalysts have potentially high reaction speeds, and tunable behavior, high durability, and recyclability. However, SACs are usually produced using high temperature processes that lead to complex and difficult to characterize structures.  In this project, Dr. Xiangfeng Duan and his team at University of California, Los Angeles are developing a general approach for the preparation of single metal atoms supported on graphine with well-defined and systematically-tunable structures. The team uses advanced X-ray analyses and electron microscopy imaging approaches to unambiguously identify the arrangement of the single metal atoms, and matches the structures with reactivities to determine the best catalysts.  The goal of this research is to define design criteria for the next generation of highly efficient electrocatalysts that could be used in mobile electronics, transportation, and renewable energy.  

SACs can combine the merits of both homogeneous catalysts (e.g., highly uniform active sites, tunable coordination environment and maximized atom utilization efficiency) and traditional heterogeneous catalysts (e.g., high durability, easy separation from the product, excellent recyclability, and easy integration with electrodes for electrocatalysis). In this project, Dr. Xiangfeng Duan is developing a general approach to prepare a series of single metal atoms embedded in two-dimensional graphene lattices with well-defined atomistic structure and systematically tunable metal centers (e.g., Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Ru, Pd, Pt), then evaluating their catalytic properties towards various electrochemical processes. The team uses  extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) and X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) analyses as well as high resolution transmission electron microscopy imaging approaches to unambiguously identify the local coordination configuration of the single metal atoms.  These are further correlated with electrocatalytic activities through both experimental and theoretical studies to establish the structure-property relationship. The general synthesis of a series of single metal sites supported by highly crystalline graphene can allow unambiguous structural identification and systematic catalytic investigations (both experimentally and theoretically). The goal is to establish structure-property correlation and thus define the critical steps toward the rational design of SACs with tailored activity, selectivity and stability.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Electrochemical processes play a central role in renewable chemical fuel generation and utilization (e.g., electrolyzers for green hydrogen production, and fuels cells that directly converts chemical energy in molecular hydrogen into electricity). The fundamental understanding of the electrochemical processes and development of efficient electrocatalysts to facilitate such processes can contribute significantly to renewable energy industry and enable a sustainable future. This project has developed a series of nanoscale and single metal atom modified electrocatalysts with precisely tailored atomistic structure, and evaluated their catalytic properties towards various electrochemical processes. Advanced electron microscopy imaging techniques and X-ray analysis were used to unambiguously identify the local atomic coordination configuration, which was further correlated with electrocatalytic activities through both experimental and theoretical studies to establish the structure-property relationship. Additionally, systematic studies were conducted to probe the local chemical environment at the catalyst-electrolyte interfaces, including the surface water orientation or protonation status, surface hydroxyl adsorption, and other cationic and anionic species, investigating how such local environment differs from bulk electrolyte and modifies the fundamental reaction mechanisms. Such studies revealed that surface water protonation status or surface adsorbed hydroxyls played a critical role in modifying the reaction pathway and reaction kinetics. Inspired by such mechanistic discovery, the project further designed several unique approaches, by using specific surface decorations, single atom modifications, or alloying/selective-dealloying process to tailor local surface atomic structure, water orientation or protonation status, and reaction intermediate binding strength, realizing electrocatalysts with superior performance particularly for alkaline hydrogen evolution and oxidation reactions. 

Together, these studies revealed critical molecular level insights on fundamental reaction mechanism of important electrochemical reactions and defines the critical intellectual underpin for the design of a new generation of electrocatalysts with tailored atomic structure, local environment and greatly improved performance. The research program provided involved students with a highly interdisciplinary education and training opportunity. The students were involved in materials synthesis, advanced microscopy imaging and analysis, spectroscopy and electrochemical studies. This interdisciplinary education provided the students with a fundamental understanding of the synthesis and evaluation of nanostructured and single atom catalysts, integration such catalysts into advanced energy devices such as electrolyzers and fuel cells. Such rigorous research training will help preparing a new generation of highly qualified workforce for renewable energy research and development. The materials discoveries made through this research are being adapted into undergraduate material chemistry lab classes to exert even broader impact.


Last Modified: 01/13/2023
Modified by: Xiangfeng Duan
